text: [Music]
the way it the way meritocracy economic
meritocracy has played out in the United
States I do have a problem with because
I think it's I I think it's a myth or
you know as I call it it's I think it's
a dead idea in that sense I think not
not necessarily among everyday Americans
but I think among the you know what you
might call the educated class the what I
call the lower upper class in the book I
think there's a sense that's built up
that people end up economically where
they deserve to and that's a function of
the kind of long transition in our
culture to the SAT driven system of
college admissions the way that young
people you know from an early age sort
of jump through those hoops and uh and
if they're successful doing that and
they're successful gaining access to the
best colleges they sort of feel kind of
entitlement to the Lion Share of the
material rewards that Society has to
offer and I think you know put aside the
fact that there's obviously no link
between that kind of Merit and any kind
of dignity or moral you know sense of
sense of worth in society but I think
it's also true and I think lower uppers
are increasingly realizing that there
isn't a link between even Merit in that
sense in that narrow sense and who ends
up the wealthiest or most or most
powerful in society you've got the rise
of uh of the undeserving ultr rich as I
call it in the book uh you know CEOs who
end up presiding over the demolition of
companies like Charles Prince at City
group or uh the fellow at Countrywide or
you know all all these folks who have
walk away with a hundred million $200
million while not only their companies
are decimated and tens of thousands of
people end up laid off but you know the
the subprime mortgage pedlers are all
retired to the country club now while
the entire country is going through the
worst crisis since the so the the
question I ask is you know how
ubiquitous does this kind of undeserving
wealth become before it becomes so
corrosive in a democracy that it wrongly
discredits capitalism altogether so I
think the lower uppers looking at that
are realizing that money doesn't
necessarily follow Merit the way they'd
quite assumed and what I think is that
is they look up and see that and these
are this is an important segment of
society these couple million people who
are senior vice presidents of marketing
they're uh they uh professors their
media observers their uh professionals
lawyers doctors who have themselves have
become to chafe a little bit and and see
the sort of unimaginable wealth above
them when they thought they themselves
were positioned to be quite comfortable
and I think that the empathy that may
awaken in them for the far greater group
that's below them on the income scale
will help them become a constituency for
the kind of uh security and opportunity
agenda we need for the country at a time
of all this rapid economic
change I don't think it's fair to blame
one party or another for this and you
know I suppose it's tempting to say
somehow it's all uh it's all a function
of of
parenting because somewhere along the
line there was a kind of ethical compass
and a especially a leadership ethic that
got lost and I think that uh you know
when I read the headlines every day it's
hard not to think that we're not seeing
a failure of Elites in every segment of
society I mean whether it's you know
Bernie maid off uh abusing uh the trust
you know this is a guy who's chairman of
the NASDAQ a respected member of the
Wall Street Community you know a Bastion
of the Jewish Community I mean it's it's
you know this kind of stuff is shocking
but you know the whole the whole idea
that you've got CEOs who walk away with
gazillions while their companies
absolutely go into the tank ought to
ought to shock us and I'm I'm actually
surprised that there's not more
political upheaval is a result of this I
think if Economic Times get worse I
think there'll be more of a backlash and
there ought to be
